The Fellowship: The Literary Lives of the Inklings

wikitext.*:
'''Leprawns''' (or '''leprechauns'''{{PE|18}}, p. 122) were creatures only appearing in some of the earliest versions of the [[legendarium]]. In one passage, the leprawns are seemingly described as a subgroup among the [[sprites]].{{LT1|III}}, p. 66 In early poems, the mysterious character [[Tinfang]] is said to have been a leprawn.{{LT1|III}}, p. 108 == Etymology == It has been suggested that the name ''leprawn'' is "Tolkien's own peculiar adaptation of ''leprechaun''".{{HM|RW}}, p. 77 == Other writings == The poem ''[[Goblin Feet]]'' speak of "tiny horns" played by "enchanted leprechauns". == Real-life == Authors Philip and Carol Zaleski recount that:Philip and Carol Zaleski, ''[[The Fellowship: The Literary Lives of the Inklings]]'', p. 370According to [[Bradley J. Birzer]], the source for this reminiscence is a letter from [[Norman Power]] to [[Clyde S. Kilby]], kept at the [[Marion E. Wade Center|Wade Collection, Marion Wade Center at Wheaton College]]: "Excerpt from a letter about JRRT, from Norman S. Power, Ladywood, Birmingham, England, author of THE FIRLAND SAGA," WCWC, Kilby Files, 3-8, "Tolkien the Man" from TOLKIEN AND THE SILMARILLION'". Cf. [http://www.facebook.com/groups/TheTolkienSociety.EducationalCharity/permalink/10157132379411068/?comment_id=10157132852931068&comment_tracking=%7B%22tn%22%3A%22R%22%7D discussion] at the Tolkien Society Facebook group (dated 13 August 2019).
''Tolkien, in response to an undergraduate's query about the truth of dragons and other legends, declared that behind such tales invariably lies something real; he then dug into his pockets and pulled out, along with a ball of string and other detritus, a small green shoe, thin and pointed in the toe, made of leathery substance that felt like reptile skin, and declared it, "stoutly and with apparent sincerity", to be a leprechaun's shoe.''
